ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was a live virtual lecture with a few asynchronous lectures.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about biomaterials, specifically ceramics, polymers, metals, composites, etc.
Introductory information on biomaterials and how the human body responds to them
Got a strong overview on materials used for implantation and drug delivery!

This course taught us about the different types of biomaterials and their applications to address medical challenges. It also taught us to think critically and synthesize the literature through our blogs.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More structure. I didn't find the way the review sessions were organized very helpful, since we didn't cover many questions each time.
I loved the information and thought it was taught in a clear way. Great class.

pro: Professor has a lot of energy and is engaging.
cons: I think the material science aspect of the course is really weak. As someone who took several material science courses before, I felt the professor was not able to explain key basic concepts in metals and ceramics. When I asked questions about the material science aspect, the answers were vague and generalized. Grading for exams also took an exorbitant amount of time, and we never had grades for the previous exam before taking the next one (with exams one month apart).
This course was strong in that it covered a very deep foundation regarding biomaterials and their real-world applications.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Maybe more virtual office hours, especially with the Professor
Asynchronous lectures were nice because they allowed us to watch in our own time, but lectures in person were also very good because it allowed us to participate and discuss in class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Only if you come from a biology focused background and have no material science experience before.

I would recommend this course to another student because it is a great course with a great professor and you will definitely learn a lot about biomedical engineering and the materials used for different medical applications.
